question: Who won the 2025 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for the novel James, a reimagining of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn from the perspective of Jim?
solution:
The correct answer is Percival Everett, who won the 2025 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for his novel James.

  • James is a radical retelling of Mark Twain’s classic, told from the perspective of Jim, the enslaved character.
  • The Pulitzer Board praised it as an “accomplished reconsideration” that illustrates the absurdity of racial supremacy and offers a new take on the search for family and freedom.
  • Everett’s Jim is secretly literate, deeply intelligent, and morally complex — a stark contrast to Twain’s portrayal.
  • The novel also won the National Book Award (2024), Kirkus Prize, and was a Booker Prize finalist.
  • Percival Everett is a Distinguished Professor of English at USC, known for genre-defying works like Erasure, which was adapted into the Oscar-winning film American Fiction.

question: Who won the 2024 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for the novel Night Watch, set in post–Civil War West Virginia?
solution:
The correct answer is Jayne Anne Phillips, who won the 2024 Pulitzer Prize for Fiction for her novel Night Watch.

  • Set in 1874, the story follows ConaLee and her mother Eliza at the Trans-Allegheny Lunatic Asylum, exploring trauma, healing, and mental illness after the Civil War.
  • The novel was praised for its lyrical prose, emotional depth, and historical realism.
  • It was also long-listed for the National Book Award and named one of the New Yorker’s Best Books of the Year.
  • Jayne Anne Phillips is a Guggenheim Fellow and author of acclaimed works like Machine Dreams and Quiet Dell.

question: Who won the 2024 National Book Award for Fiction for the novel James, a reimagining of The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn?
solution:
The correct answer is Percival Everett, who won the 2024 National Book Award for Fiction for his novel James.

  • James retells Mark Twain’s classic from the perspective of Jim, the enslaved character, giving him agency, intellect, and emotional depth.
  • The judges praised it as a “surgical disarticulation of the bones that hold American racialism in place”, celebrating literacy, self-naming, and freedom.
  • The novel also won the Pulitzer Prize (2025) and the Kirkus Prize, and was a Booker Prize finalist.
  • Percival Everett is a Distinguished Professor of English at USC, known for works like Erasure, which inspired the Oscar-winning film American Fiction.

question: Who won the 2025 Women’s Prize for Fiction for the debut novel The Safekeep?
option_3: Yael van der Wouden
solution:
The 2025 Women’s Prize for Fiction was awarded to Yael van der Wouden for her debut novel The Safekeep.

  • Set in 1961 Netherlands, it explores repressed desires, Holocaust trauma, and family secrets.
  • Judges hailed it as “a classic in the making”.
  • Yael is a Dutch author and creative writing lecturer, and her novel was acquired in a highly competitive auction.
  • She dedicated the win to the trans community, openly sharing her identity as intersex.
  • 2024 Winner: VV Ganeshananthan for Brotherless Night

question: Who won the 2025 International Booker Prize for the short story collection Heart Lamp?
solution:
The 2025 International Booker Prize was awarded to Banu Mushtaq for Heart Lamp, a collection of 12 short stories originally written in Kannada.

  • It was translated into English by Deepa Bhasthi, who also became the first Indian translator to win this prize.
  • This marks the first time a Kannada-language work and a short story collection have won the award.
  • The stories explore Muslim women’s lives in southern India, highlighting themes of patriarchy, resilience, and social justice.
  • Mushtaq is a lawyer, journalist, and activist, known for her role in the Bandaya Sahitya movement.
  • 2024 Winner: Michael Hofmann (Translator) & jenny Erpenbeck for Kairos

question: Who won the 2024 National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction for the novel My Friends?
solution:
The 2024 National Book Critics Circle Award for Fiction was awarded to Hisham Matar for his novel My Friends.

  • The story follows Khaled, a Libyan exile in London, navigating grief, friendship, and political displacement.
  • It spans three decades, exploring themes of literary obsession, revolution, and identity in exile.
  • Judges praised it as a gripping and beautiful portrait of dissidence and emotional survival.
  • Matar is a Pulitzer Prize-winning author, known for The Return and In the Country of Men.

question: Who won the 2024 Kirkus Prize for Fiction for the novel James?
solution:
Percival Everett won the 2024 Kirkus Prize for Fiction for his novel James.

  • The book reimagines The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn from the perspective of Jim, the enslaved character.
  • It was praised as “enthralling” and “a necessary companion to Twain’s masterpiece”.
  • James also received the National Book Award, Pulitzer Prize, and was a Booker Prize finalist.
  • Everett is a Distinguished Professor at USC, and his novel Erasure inspired the Oscar-winning film American Fiction.
  • 2023 Winner: James McBride for The Heaven & Earth Grocery Store

question: Who won the 2025 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for the novel Small Rain?
solution:
Garth Greenwell won the 2025 PEN/Faulkner Award for Fiction for his novel Small Rain.

  • The story explores illness, identity, and hospital life, told with visceral detail and precise language.
  • Judges praised it as a “dazzling, gutting, unforgettable novel” that affirms the power of art, love, and connection.
  • Greenwell is known for What Belongs to You and Cleanness, and is a Distinguished Writer in Residence at NYU.
  • Finalists included works by Percival Everett, Danzy Senna, and Susan Muaddi Darraj.
  • 2024 Winner: Claire Jimennez for What Happened to Ruthy Ramirez

question: Sad Grownups, a debut short story collection by Amy Stuber, won which award in 2025?
option_4: PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize
solution:
Amy Stuber won the 2025 PEN/Robert W. Bingham Prize for Debut Fiction for Sad Grownups.

  • The book features 12 stories that explore womanhood, labor, and emotional complexities, blending humor and poignancy.
  • Judges praised it as “a collection full of surprises”.
  • It was published by Stillhouse Press, and marked Stuber’s first book after three decades of writing.
  • Her work has appeared in Ploughshares, American Short Fiction, and New England Review.

question: Who won the 2024 Sushila Devi Award for her novel Taxi?
solution:
Manjula Padmanabhan won the 2024 Sushila Devi Award for her novel Taxi, presented at the Bhopal Literature and Art Festival in January 2025.

  • The story follows Maddy Sen, a US-educated woman taxi driver who is asked to dress as a male chauffeur, challenging gender norms and social stereotypes.
  • The novel explores cross-dressing, gendered public spaces, and women’s autonomy.
  • The jury praised its nuanced storytelling and ability to illuminate contemporary social issues.
  • The award honors the best fiction book by a woman author and includes a ₹2 lakh cash prize.

question: Pachrang Chol Pahar Sakhi Ri, a literary criticism book by Dr. Madhav Hada, won which award in 2022?
solution:
Dr. Madhav Hada received the 32nd Bihari Puraskar (2022) for his book Pachrang Chol Pahar Sakhi Ri.

  • The book, published in 2015, is a literary critique centered on Meera Bai, the medieval Bhakti poet.
  • It explores literature, media, culture, and history, offering a fresh perspective on Meera’s spiritual and poetic legacy.
  • The award is presented by the KK Birla Foundation to a Rajasthani author for an outstanding Hindi or Rajasthani work published in the last 10 years.
  • It includes a ₹2.5 lakh cash prize, a plaque, and a citation.

question: Who won the 2025 Thakazhi Memorial Literary Award for contributions to Malayalam literature?
solution:
K.P. Sudheera won the 2025 Thakazhi Memorial Literary Award for her exceptional work in Malayalam literature.

  • She has authored over 85 books, covering genres like novels, poetry, travelogues, biographies, and children’s literature.
  • Her works have been translated into Hindi, Tamil, Telugu, and Kannada, expanding her reach across India.
  • The award was presented on April 17, the birth anniversary of legendary author Thakazhi Sivasankara Pillai, known for Chemmeen.
  • Organized by the Thakazhi Smaraka Samithi, the award includes a ₹50,000 cash prize, citation, and memento.
  • Sudheera is also recognized for her literary activism and support for women’s voices in literature.
  • 2024 winner: MK Sanu

question: Who won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Award in the English language category for the novel Spirit Nights?
solution:
Easterine Kire won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Award (English) for her novel Spirit Nights.

  • The book draws from Chang Naga tribal folklore of Nagaland, blending myth, memory, and fictional storytelling.
  • Published by Simon & Schuster India, it explores darkness, spirituality, and ancestral wisdom.
  • Kire is a renowned Naga writer, known for portraying Northeast Indian culture and history.
  • She previously won the Bal Sahitya Puraskar (2018) and The Hindu Literary Prize (2015).
  • The award includes a ₹1 lakh cash prize, engraved copper plaque, and shawl, and will be presented on March 8, 2025, in Delhi.

question: Who won the 2025 Luminous Lummer Dai Literary Award for contributions to literature and tribal studies?
solution:
Ramchandra Chutia won the 2025 Luminous Lummer Dai Literary Award, presented by the Arunachal Pradesh Literary Society on June 1, 2025, during the 85th birth anniversary of Lummer Dai.

  • He has authored 29 books, including 8 on socio-anthropological aspects of Arunachal tribes.
  • His works span poetry, novels, short stories, travelogues, and memoirs, written in Assamese and English.
  • Chutia began his career in 1971 as a teacher in Subansiri district, and retired as Principal of Govt HS School, Doimukh in 2010.
  • The award includes a ₹50,000 cash prize, citation, memento, and books, honoring his literary and cultural contributions to Arunachal Pradesh.
  • 2024 Winner= Wangsam Zongsam & Thajam Aboh

question: Who won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Award in the Hindi language category for the poetry collection Main Jab Tak Aai Bahar?
solution:
Gagan Gill won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Award (Hindi) for her poetry collection Main Jab Tak Aai Bahar.

  • The book explores feminine identity, existence, and emotional transformation, blending personal memory with philosophical depth.
  • Gill is a renowned Hindi poet, known for her introspective and lyrical style.
  • The award honors outstanding literary works in 24 Indian languages and includes a ₹1 lakh cash prize, engraved copper plaque, and shawl.
  • It will be presented on March 8, 2025, in New Delhi.

question: Who won the 2024 Booker Prize for the novel Orbital?
solution:
Samantha Harvey won the 2024 Booker Prize for her novel Orbital.

  • Set aboard the International Space Station, the novel follows six astronauts as they orbit Earth, witnessing 16 sunrises and sunsets in a single day.
  • It explores themes of grief, solitude, and the fragility of Earth, blending lyrical prose with philosophical depth.
  • At just 136 pages, it is one of the shortest Booker winners ever and the first space-set novel to win the prize.
  • Harvey is a British author, previously longlisted for the Booker in 2009, and known for her formally inventive storytelling.
  • The award includes a £50,000 cash prize and global recognition.

question: Who won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Award in the Urdu language category for the book Bain-ul-Uloomi Tanqeed?
option_4: Mirza Khalil Ahmed Beg
solution:
Ateequllah won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Award (Urdu) for his book Bain-ul-Uloomi Tanqeed, a work of literary criticism.

  • The book was selected by a three-member jury and approved by the Sahitya Akademi Executive Board.
  • It explores interdisciplinary approaches to Urdu criticism, blending literature, philosophy, and cultural analysis.
  • The award includes a ₹1 lakh cash prize, engraved copper plaque, and shawl, and will be presented on March 8, 2025, in New Delhi.
  • Ateequllah is a respected Urdu scholar, known for his contributions to modern literary theory and critical discourse.

question: Who won the 2024 JCB Prize for Literature for the novel Lorenzo Searches for the Meaning of Life?
solution:
Upamanyu Chatterjee won the 2024 JCB Prize for Literature for his novel Lorenzo Searches for the Meaning of Life.

  • Published by Speaking Tiger Books, the novel follows an ordinary man’s spiritual journey, blending humor, introspection, and existential themes.
  • It was awarded at the JCB India Headquarters, Ballabhgarh, and includes a ₹25 lakh cash prize.
  • The trophy, titled Mirror Melting, was designed by Delhi artist duo Thukral and Tagra.
  • This was the 7th and final edition of the JCB Prize, which was discontinued in 2025 after seven impactful years.

question: Who won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Yuva Puraskar in the English language category for the memoir Homeless: Growing up Lesbian and Dyslexic in India?
solution:
K. Vaishali won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Yuva Puraskar (English) for her memoir Homeless: Growing up Lesbian and Dyslexic in India.

  • The book is a powerful personal narrative that explores queer identity, neurodiversity, and social exclusion in India.
  • Vaishali is the first openly lesbian and dyslexic writer to win this award.
  • The Yuva Puraskar honors young writers under 35 across 24 Indian languages.
  • The award includes a ₹50,000 cash prize, engraved copper plaque, and shawl, and will be presented at a special ceremony in 2025.
  • Other winners include Gaurav Pandey (Hindi), Ramesh Karthik Nayak (Telugu), and Javed Amber Misbahi (Urdu).

question: Who won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Bal Sahitya Puraskar in the Hindi language category for the book 51 Baal Kahaniyan?
solution:
Devender Kumar won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Bal Sahitya Puraskar (Hindi) for his book 51 Baal Kahaniyan.

  • The book is a collection of children’s stories, praised for its simplicity, imagination, and moral depth.
  • It was selected by a three-member jury and approved by the Sahitya Akademi Executive Board.
  • The award honors excellence in children’s literature across 24 Indian languages.
  • It includes a ₹50,000 cash prize, engraved copper plaque, and shawl, and will be presented at a special ceremony in 2025.

question: Who won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Bal Sahitya Puraskar in the English language category?
solution:
Nandini Sengupta won the 2024 Sahitya Akademi Bal Sahitya Puraskar (English) for her historical fiction book The Blue Horse and Other Amazing Animals from Indian History.

  • The book presents Indian history through the lens of animals, such as Akbar’s cheetah, Shivaji’s loyal dog Waghya, and Maharana Pratap’s horse Chetak.
  • It combines folklore, inscriptions, miniature paintings, and tribal songs to create engaging narratives for young readers.
  • Sengupta is a journalist and author based in Pondicherry, known for her Gupta Empire Trilogy and The Story of Kalidasa.
  • The book was also shortlisted for the AutHer Awards 2021 and featured in the Parag Honour List.
  • The award includes a ₹50,000 cash prize, an engraved copper plaque, and a shawl, to be presented in 2025.

question: Who won the 2024 Jnanpith Award for outstanding contribution to Hindi literature?
solution:
Vinod Kumar Shukla won the 59th Jnanpith Award (2024) for his exceptional contribution to Hindi literature.

  • He is the first recipient from Chhattisgarh and the 12th Hindi writer to receive this prestigious honor.
  • His notable works include Naukar Ki Kameez, Deewar Mein Ek Khidki Rehti Thi, and Khilega To Dekhenge.
  • His novel Naukar Ki Kameez was adapted into a film by Mani Kaul in 1999.
  • Shukla also received the Sahitya Akademi Award (1999) and the 2023 PEN/Nabokov Award for international literature.
  • The award includes ₹11 lakh, a bronze Saraswati statue, and a citation, presented by Bharatiya Jnanpith.
  • 2023 winners of the Jnanpith Award were Gulzar (Urdu) and Jagadguru Rambhadracharya (Sanskrit).

question: Who won the 34th Saraswati Samman (2024) for the Sanskrit work Swaminarayana Siddhanta Sudha?
solution:
Bhadreshdas Swami, a renowned Sanskrit scholar and monk, won the 34th Saraswati Samman (2024) for his philosophical treatise Swaminarayana Siddhanta Sudha.

  • The book presents the Akshar-Purushottam Darshan, a distinct school of Vedanta philosophy rooted in the teachings of Bhagwan Swaminarayan.
  • It is recognized as a comprehensive commentary on the Prasthanatrayi (Upanishads, Bhagavad Gita, and Brahmasutras).
  • Swami is affiliated with the BAPS Swaminarayan Sanstha, and his work has been accepted by major academic institutions including Banaras Hindu University and Delhi University.
  • The award includes ₹15 lakh, a citation, and a plaque, presented by the K.K. Birla Foundation.
  • 2023 winner of the Saraswati Samman was Prabha Varma for his Malayalam verse novel Roudra Sathwikam, which explores power, politics, and dharma through poetic narration.

question: Who won the 34th Vyas Samman (2024) for the Hindi novel Kaun Des Ko Vasi: Venu Ki Diary?
solution:
Suryabala received the 34th Vyas Samman (2024) for her novel Kaun Des Ko Vasi: Venu Ki Diary.

  • Published in 2018, the novel explores the cultural and ideological conflicts faced by Indian youth living abroad, especially in America.
  • It portrays the identity crisis, alienation, and spiritual detachment experienced by the diaspora.
  • Suryabala, born in Varanasi in 1943, has authored over 50 works, including novels, biographies, and children’s literature, many adapted into TV serials.
  • The award is presented by the K.K. Birla Foundation, and includes ₹4 lakh, a citation, and a plaque.
  • 2023 winner of the Vyas Samman was Pushpa Bharati for her memoir Yaadein, Yaadein aur Yaadein, which reflects on the lives of iconic Hindi literary figures.

question: Who won the 2023 Sahitya Akademi Award in the English language category?
solution:
Neelum Saran Gour won the 2023 Sahitya Akademi Award (English) for her novel Requiem in Raga Janaki.

  • The novel is set in Allahabad during the British Raj, and chronicles the life of Janki Bai Illahabadi, a celebrated classical singer.
  • It blends historical fiction with musical and cultural heritage, offering a vivid portrayal of early 20th-century India.
  • Gour is a renowned author and former professor at Allahabad University, with over six novels, four short story collections, and two nonfiction books to her credit.
  • Her work has been published by Penguin, HarperCollins, and Rupa, and she has received fellowships in England, Scotland, and Spain.
  • The award includes ₹1 lakh, an engraved copper plaque, and a shawl, presented by the Sahitya Akademi.
  • 2024 winner of the Sahitya Akademi Award (English) was Easterine Kire for her novel Spirit Nights.
